sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: The GNOME On-Screen Keyboard (GOK) application displays virtual keyboards on your screen that you can operate using the standard mouse pointer or an alternative pointing device. &app; displays the following types of keyboards:

listitem.para: Compose keyboard
The compose keyboard enables you to type alphanumeric characters to compose text by selecting the characters from the keyboard.
Dynamic keyboards
&app; generates keyboards that contain keys to represent the applications that are running on your desktop or the menus that are contained in an application.

sect2.title: To Start &appname;
sect2.para: You can start &app; in the following ways:

listitem.para:
Choose
Applications Accessibility On-Screen Keyboard .
Execute the following command: gok
You can use the -d option to specify default settings.

sect2.title: When You Start &appname;
sect2.para: If support for assistive technologies is not enabled on your system when you start &app;, the following Warning window appears:

To use the full capabilities of &app;, activate the Enable and Log Out button. When you log in again and start &app;, support for assistive technologies is enabled and the Information window is not displayed.
When you start &app; with support for assistive technologies enabled, the GOK - main window appears:
The GOK - main window contains the following keys that you can activate to display a variety of different keyboards:

Displays keys to enable you to move or resize the GOK windows.

Displays keys to enable you to start other applications.
Displays keys to enable you to navigate and use the desktop and the applications that are currently running on the desktop.
Displays keys to enable you to access information about the GOK application such as Help and Preferences, and also to exit the application.

sect2.title: To Use the Compose Keyboard
sect2.para: To use the compose keyboard feature of &app;, activate Compose in the GOK - main window. The GOK - Keyboard window is displayed.
The &app; compose keyboard is a standard alphanumeric keyboard. You can customize the type of compose keyboard that &app; displays in the GOK Preferences dialog. See for more information.
&app; uses the spaces at the top of the keyboard for word prediction, if you enable the word prediction options in the GOK Preferences dialog.
The method that you use to select and activate the keys on the keyboards depends on the option that you select in the GOK Preferences dialog. See for more information.
To return to the GOK - main window at any time, activate Back.
To hide the keyboard, activate Hide. To display the keyboard again, activate Show.

sect3.para: To access standard text editing functions from the &app; standard keyboard, activate Edit.

note.para: The Edit key is only available if you have a document open in a text editor application.

sect3.title: To Display a Numeric Keypad Only
sect3.para: To display the numeric keypad only on the screen, activate Num Pad in the GOK - Keyboard window.

sect3.title: To Launch a Text Editor and Start Entering Text in a New Document
sect3.para: To use &app; to launch a text editor and start to enter text in a new document, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: In the GOK - main window, activate Launcher.
In the GOK - launcher window, activate Text Editor.
In the GOK - launcher window, activate back to return to the GOK - main window.
In the GOK - main window, activate Compose to display the compose keyboard.

sect3.para: You can now use the compose keyboard to enter text in the document.

sect2.title: To Navigate and Use the Desktop and Desktop Applications
sect2.para: To move focus around the desktop environment, activate the Activate key in the GOK - main window. The GOK - Window List window contains keys that represent the desktop components and applications that are currently running. For example, the GOK - Window List window may contain the following keys:

sect2.title: To Access Application Menus
sect2.para: &app; dynamically generates keyboards to reflect the menus on the application that currently has focus. To view and access the menus for the current application, activate Menus in the GOK - main window. The GOK - Menus window contains a key for each menu that is contained on the application menubar. For example, if the Terminal application currently has focus, and you activate Menus in the GOK - main window, the GOK - Menus window contains the following keys:
When you activate a key that represents a menu, a new keyboard is displayed that contains a key for each menu item that is contained on that menu in the application.

sect2.title: To Access Application Toolbars
sect2.para: &app; dynamically generates keyboards to reflect the toolbar items on the application that currently has focus, if the application contains a toolbar. To view and access the toolbar items for the current application, activate Toolbars in the GOK - main window. The GOK - Toolbars window contains a key for each toolbar item that is contained on the application toolbar.

sect2.title: To Quit GOK
sect2.para: Perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Activate GOK in the GOK - main window.
Activate Quit GOK.
Activate Really Quit.

sect1.title: Preferences
sect1.para: To open the Preferences dialog, activate GOK in the &app; - main window, then activate Preferences. The GOK Preferences dialog contains the following tabbed sections:

listitem.para: The Appearance tabbed section contains preferences to enable you to customize how the &app; windows and keys are displayed.
The Keyboards tabbed section enables you to specify the type of keyboard that &app; displays when you click the Compose key.

In the context of &app;, an action is a method by which you activate keys on the &app; keyboards. The Actions tabbed section enables you to select predefined actions or create new actions to suit your requirements.
The Feedback tabbed section enables you to specify how you want to receive feedback when you successfully activate a key. You can also create new feedback methods to suit your requirements.
The Access Methods tabbed section enables you to specify how you access and select keys from the &app; keyboards.
The Prediction tabbed section enables you to select word completion or command prediction options.

sect2.title: Access Methods Preferences

listitem.para: There are seven access methods defined in &app; for selecting a key on a keyboard, as follows:
This method enables you to use four switches to move the mouse pointer around the keyboard in four directions; up, down, left, and right. You use a fifth switch to activate the selected key.

This method enables you to press a switch to start selecting the rows and keys on the keyboard in sequence. When the application reaches the key that you require, you press another switch to activate the key.
This method enables you to use a direct mouse click. You use the mouse pointer to select a key and then press a switch to activate the key.
This method enables you to use a mouse or other pointing device to position the mouse pointer over a key for a specified period of time to select and activate the key.

This method enables you to press and hold a switch to start selecting the rows and keys of the keyboard. When you release the switch, the application stops the selection operation on the current key and you press another switch to activate the selected key.

This method enables you to press a switch to start the application to automatically select each key on the keyboard in sequence. When the application reaches the key that you require, you press another switch to activate the key.

This method enables you to press and hold a switch to select each key on the keyboard. When you release the switch, the application stops the selection operation on the current key and you press another switch to activate the selected key.

sect2.para: Depending on the access method that you select, the Operation, Feedback, and Options preferences differ, as described in the following sections.
